newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: PRESS DIGEST - CENTRAL/EAST EUROPE - NOV 14.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - CENTRAL/EAST EUROPE - NOV 14.

text.p: NOTE - Press Digest contains Austria, Czech Republic, Slovakia, Bulgaria and Croatia.
AUSTRIA
DER STANDARD
- Social Democrat Social Affairs Minister Franz Hums and the junior coalition conservative partners are locked in heated debate over new laws on flexible work hours and night work.
- Vienna's businesses are pessimistic about the region, a study by Vienna's Chamber of Economy says.
- European Union telecoms commissioner Martin Bangemann has criticised Austria's sluggish liberalisation of the market, saying it is harming Austria's economy.

- Steelmaker VA Stahl has intensified cooperation with German steelmaker Kloeckner by exchanging the bulk of its trade business for the takeover of two of Kloeckner's Steel Service Centers in Switzerland.
- Gustav Raab, secretary general of the savings banks' union, said he would like GiroCredit to have a say in the Post's savings bank PSK which is due to be privatised.
DIE PRESSE
- Austrians have reduced their savings deposits due to public spending cuts. It is expected that this trend will continue in 1997.
- Austria's conservative-ruled provinces are vetoeing plans by Hums for call duty for specialist doctors on weekends in hospitals.
KURIER
- Economics Minister Hannes Farnleitner is ignoring protests by traders and trade unions against a new ruling for longer shopping hours.
WIRTSCHAFTSBLATT
- Die Erste savings bank has joined the Austro-Italian-German consortium around insurer EA-Generali bidding for the government's stake in Creditanstalt.
CZECH REPUBLIC

HOSPODARSKE NOVINY - People and companies are putting less money into banks than in previous years in real terms. Crown deposits increased by only 26 billion crowns in the first nine months, a growth of 2.8 percent compared with inflation of around nine percent.

- The government's plan to remove debt from small banks still has not been utilised by any institution. While less than ten of thirteen possible banks have expressed interest, the Czech National Bank is still discussing terms and conditions with them.
- Czech people are paying more for culture and leisure (by 49 percent) when compared with a year ago. People are also paying 35 percent more for nursery education and 34 percent on clothing.

- Petr Necas, the chairman of the parliamentary committee for defense and security, stated that he does "not consider the purchase of new fighter aircraft from Western suppliers to be realistic, nor is it even important."
- Vitkovice, one of the country's three largest foundries, faces losses of 300 million crowns by the end of the year.

- McDonald's expects to have 33 fast food restaurants open by the end of the year in the Czech Republic, including 13 drive-in restaurants. At the beginning of the year there were 23 restaurants open.

- Germany's Wintershall, one of the candidates for supplying natural gas to the Czech Republic, is already active in the Czech Republic. "We have had a contract with Transgas for five years now," according to the Arnost Thon, the manager of Wintershall's Czech daughter company, Wintershall Gas a.s..

MLADA FRONTA DNES - People who use monetary insurance as a method for short-term savings will have to leave their money in these funds longer now. The minister of Finance has increased the minimum length for leaving money in these funds from one to three years.

- Even though the consumption of beer has decreased this year in Germany, exports of Czech beer to Germany have increased from 220 thousand hectolitres to 247 thousand hectolitres in the first ten months of 1996. Slovakia remains the largest market for Czech beer exports with 262 thousand hectolitres. -- Prague Newsroom, +42-2-2423-0003
SLOVAKIA

NARODNA OBRODA - Frantisek Gaulider, a member of the ruling Movement for a Democratic Slovakia (HZDS) who quit the party's parliamentary club last week, said he did not plan to hand back his mandate despite the pressure on him from the HZDS club to do so.

- Losses of some six billion crowns at agricultural firms -- the result of differences between production costs and revenues -- may be partially solved by an increase in state subsidies, Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar said.
- Productivity in the agricluture industry in the first half of this year decreased by some 16 percent, year-on-year.

- Slovakia's deposits of crude oil are estimated at some 95 million tonnes, and of natural gas at about 430 billion cubic metres. Slovakia's own resources, at present, cover only 0.5 percent of its oil consumption and up to 10 percent of gas consumption.

HOSPODARSKE NOVINY - The state-run social insurance company, Socialna Poistovna, said it was owed some 10 billion crowns as of September 30 on delays of compulsory contributions by companies for their employees.

- Some 167 construction companies were included in the second wave of privatisation by the end of September, of which 54 had already been fully-privatised, six partially-privatised and 40 are still awaiting a privatisation decision. Some 67 companies are in liquidation procedures.
- Engineering company ZTS Trstena will supply heavy mechanisms for wood industry in Bosnia. The contract is worth some 100 million crowns.
- Slovakia's largest drug producer, Slovakofarma, said it expected its revenues to total 4.4 billion crowns this year.

PRAVDA - The trade union at steel producer VSZ said it would create an independet trade organisation, open for all employees in the engineering and steel industry. VSZ unions have already stopped paying dues to the OZ KOVO, the steel and engineering trade union. -- Bratislava Newsroom, 42-7-563-3687
BULGARIA
24 CHASA
-- Bulgaria's Foreign Minister Georgi Pirinski resigned on Tuesday saying the Socialist cabinet did not have enough public support to carry out necessary economic reforms.
Prime minister Zhan Videnov said he would not appoint a new foreign minister before the end of next month and one of Pirinski's deputies will take on his duties under Videnov's supervision.

-- Bulgaria's Podkrepa trade union leader Konstantin Trenchev appealed to President Zhelyu Zhelev to step down before his term expires in January and give way to the president-elect Petar Stoyanov to speed up democratic reforms in the country.
PARI

-- Bulgaria's Chief Prosecutor's office has launched an investigation against officials from the private Central Co-operative Bank on charges of misapropriation of six million dollars deposited in the bank in April/May 1995 by a Russian businessman, chief prosecutor Ivan Tatarchev told reporters.

-- Bulgaria's finance and ecomomic development ministries will carry out a test simulation of an introduction of a currency board in the country and the results of the test are expected by the end of November, Social Care Minister Mincho Koralski said.
-- Bulgaria's Securities and Stock Exchanges Commision issued licenses to the last two of Bulgaria's 81 voucher privatisation funds that have applied for licensing by the October 7 deadline.
TRUD
-- British Enterprise Oil company will start offshore drilling for natural gas near the Bulgarian Black Sea cape Kaliakra, a company official said.
-- Energy prices are expected to rise by 14-21 percent if the government approves the rise at its regular meeting on Thursday.
KONTINENT

-- Bulgaria's Privatisation Agency executive director Vesselin Blagoev said he had offered 90 Bulgarian state companies for privatisation to Russian entrepreneurs during a visit to Moscow. -- Sofia Newsroom, (++359-2) 981 8569
CROATIA
VJESNIK
- Opposition storms out of a House of Representatives session and decides to boycott parliament sessions for a month.
- The Zagreb city council proposes a 14 percent 1997 budget increase to 2.7 billion kuna.
- Government and trade unions reach agreement on wage increase.
- Petrol goes up over 3 percent, diesel fuels between 5.8 and 8.4 percent. INA also to increase the price of natural gas for distributors some 10 percent.
VECERNJI LIST
- State privatisation agency continues probes into buyouts in 103 more firms. Only four of more than 1,000 credit arrangements for the purchase of shares have been annulled.
- Draft proposal of the new pension act to change status of invalidity as a basis for early retirement.
- Metal workers hold protests over unpaid wages. Union leaders say up to 10,000 of them may lose their jobs by year-end.
- Chief state auditor Sima Krasic is staying in office although, according to rumours, there have been moves to replace her.
SLOBODNA DALMACIJA

- They want to provoke a state crisis, says parliament deputy speaker, Vladimir Seks commenting on the latest opposition decision to boycott the work of the parliament. -- Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
